document_metadata.title: Decision Authority Hypotheses - Rackspace Technology, Inc.
document_metadata.note: Per Stage 0.3 requirements: hypotheses must be falsifiable, structural (not performance-based), evidence-based (not narrative-based)

hypothesis_framework.hypothesis: Apollo Global Management exercises shadow control over strategic decisions through 57% voting majority, rendering formal board governance and CEO authority subordinate to Apollo's capital recovery objectives
supporting_evidence_sought: Apollo board representation despite independent chairman appointment
Strategic decisions (M&A, CEO appointments, business model pivots) that align with Apollo interests but contradict public shareholder value maximization
CEO turnover pattern suggesting board (Apollo) directs leadership changes
Strategic review initiated and abandoned without public shareholder input
Evidence that Apollo's stranded capital position (paid $4.3B 2016, current stake worth ~$68M) drives decisions toward cash generation vs growth
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Board decisions where independent directors prevailed over Apollo representatives
Evidence that independent Chairman (Jeffrey Benjamin) can override Apollo on material matters
Strategic initiatives pursued despite Apollo opposition
Apollo reducing board representation when independent chairman appointed (did not occur—Mahidhar joined when Sambur departed)

supporting: Apollo 57% ownership confirmed (SEC filings)
Strategic review 2022-2023 abandoned—Apollo-controlled board could not find acceptable buyer
CEO transition Sept 2022 (Jones to Maletira) during failed strategic review
Apollo board representation maintained: Mahidhar joined Jan 2025 when Sambur departed
Independent Chairman Benjamin appointed Jan 2025 AFTER key strategic decisions made (review abandoned 2023)
Apollo paid $4.3B 2016, current market cap $120M—confirms stranded capital position
disconfirming: No evidence found of independent directors overriding Apollo on material decisions
No evidence of Apollo reducing board influence when independent chairman appointed

hypothesis_framework.notes: Hypothesis strongly supported. Apollo's 57% voting control provides absolute authority over shareholder decisions. Independent board oversight is performative—cannot override Apollo's voting majority. CEO authority subordinate to Apollo strategic direction. Apollo's stranded capital position ($4.3B investment, $68M current value) creates misalignment with public shareholders—Apollo optimizes for capital recovery, public shareholders for growth/appreciation.

hypothesis_framework.hypothesis: Business Unit Presidents have title suggesting P&L accountability but lack real decision authority—actual authority concentrated at CEO level, creating CEO bottleneck
supporting_evidence_sought: BU President departures without immediate replacement
CEO assuming BU leadership roles directly
Absence of BU President strategic decision-making in public forums (earnings calls)
Customer escalations within BU unable to reach BU-level decision-maker
Evidence of BU-level issues escalating to CEO rather than resolved at BU level
disconfirming_evidence_sought: BU Presidents making strategic announcements independently
Separate P&L disclosures with BU President accountability statements
Evidence of BU Presidents resolving cross-functional issues within their units without CEO involvement
Immediate replacement of departed BU Presidents (indicating role importance/authority)

supporting: Private Cloud President Lillie departed Jan 2025, CEO assumed role directly—no replacement appointed
Public Cloud President not named in public disclosures—suggests low organizational visibility
CEO articulates strategy for both BUs in earnings calls—no BU President involvement evident
Customer complaints: 'cannot escalate to senior management'—indicates escalation doesn't reach BU level
P&L disclosed by BU but no indication BU Presidents have autonomous decision authority
disconfirming: No evidence found of BU Presidents making independent strategic decisions
No evidence of immediate replacement when Lillie departed—CEO backfill instead

hypothesis_framework.notes: Hypothesis supported. BU President roles exist for reporting structure clarity but lack real decision authority. CEO concentration of operational authority creates bottleneck—CEO cannot scale to all BU-level issues but BU Presidents lack authority to decide independently. Organizational structure suggests federation (two BUs) but decision authority remains centralized (CEO).

hypothesis_framework.hypothesis: Sales organization has deal-making authority misaligned with delivery profitability accountability, creating systematic margin erosion and customer execution failures
supporting_evidence_sought: Margin erosion patterns coinciding with revenue bookings
Customer complaints about execution failures suggesting capability overselling
CEO policy statements attempting to correct sales behavior (e.g., profitability discipline)
Sales force turnover or 'refresh' indicating incentive/authority misalignment
Evidence of delivery organization lacking authority to veto unprofitable deals pre-sale
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence of deal approval process requiring delivery/finance sign-off before booking
Sales compensation tied to profitability/retention, not just bookings
Stable margins despite revenue growth
High NPS/CSAT scores contradicting execution failure complaints

supporting: Margin decline: Private Cloud -13% YoY, Public Cloud -3% YoY
Q4 2024 CEO statement: 'walk away from unprofitable deals'—indicates prior deals unprofitable
Q3 2024 sales organization 'refresh'—indicates personnel changes needed to fix misalignment
Customer complaints (BBB, Trustpilot): execution failures suggesting overselling
400+ quota-bearing reps with unclear deal approval thresholds
disconfirming: No evidence found of delivery organization having pre-sale veto authority
No evidence of sales compensation tied to profitability vs bookings (unknown—requires proxy statement)

hypothesis_framework.notes: Hypothesis supported. Sales authority (deal-making) separated from delivery accountability (profitability, customer satisfaction) creates systematic problems. CEO attempting to correct through policy ('walk away' Q4 2024) and personnel changes ('refresh' Q3 2024), but enforcement mechanism unclear at 400+ rep scale. Authority/accountability mismatch persists until sales incentives realigned and/or delivery gains pre-sale veto authority.

hypothesis_framework.hypothesis: Customer support escalations fail due to absence of empowered decision-maker between frontline support and CEO—issues stall in organizational gap
supporting_evidence_sought: Customer complaints describing escalation attempts that fail to reach decision-maker
Pattern of issues spanning multiple tickets/engineers without resolution
Absence of VP Customer Support or Chief Customer Officer role in disclosed leadership
Evidence that BU Presidents do not own customer escalation resolution
CEO cannot scale to individual customer issues
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence of VP Customer Support or CCO with escalation resolution authority
Customer escalation playbook routing to empowered BU-level decision-maker
Declining complaint trends indicating escalation process improvement
High NPS/CSAT scores contradicting complaint patterns

supporting: BBB complaints: 'multiple tickets, dozens of engineers, no ownership, cannot escalate to senior management'
Trustpilot: 'horrible customer support, nobody responds timely, consistently getting worse'
Gartner Peer Insights: conflicting advice from multiple engineers, no single point of accountability
No VP Customer Support or Chief Customer Officer disclosed in filings or earnings calls
BU President Lillie departure with CEO backfill—indicates BU presidents lack operational authority including customer escalations
disconfirming: No evidence found of empowered customer support executive below CEO level
No evidence of escalation process reaching decision-maker—complaints describe dead-end paths

hypothesis_framework.notes: Hypothesis strongly supported. Customer escalations stall in organizational gap between frontline support (lacks cross-functional authority) and CEO (cannot scale to individual issues). No intermediate decision-maker (VP Support, CCO, empowered BU President) evident. Complaints span multiple platforms (BBB, Trustpilot, Gartner) and time periods—indicates structural escalation failure, not isolated incidents.

hypothesis_framework.hypothesis: Cross-functional conflicts escalate directly to CEO without intermediate governance layer (no standing operating committee or cross-functional council), creating CEO bottleneck
supporting_evidence_sought: Absence of disclosed operating committee, deal review board, or cross-functional council
Evidence of cross-functional conflicts requiring CEO intervention
CEO involvement in tactical decisions (pricing, deal approval, operational issues)
BU Presidents lacking authority to resolve cross-functional issues within their units
Pattern of issues escalating to CEO level rather than resolved by standing governance body
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Disclosure of standing operating committee with cross-functional decision authority
Evidence of deal review board with authority to resolve sales/delivery/finance conflicts
Risk committee or enterprise risk governance forum making operational risk decisions
BU Presidents or functional VPs resolving cross-functional conflicts without CEO escalation

supporting: No operating committee, deal review board, or cross-functional council disclosed in filings or earnings calls
CEO articulates all strategic decisions in earnings calls—no delegation to governance forums
BU Presidents lack authority (evidenced by Lillie departure, CEO backfill)
Q4 2024 CEO 'walk away from unprofitable deals' policy—tactical pricing decision at CEO level
Customer complaints: 'cannot reach senior management'—suggests no standing escalation forum routing issues to governance body
disconfirming: No evidence found of standing cross-functional governance forums
No evidence of BU or functional leaders resolving cross-functional conflicts independently

hypothesis_framework.notes: Hypothesis supported. Cross-functional governance occurs through CEO ad hoc intervention, not standing forums. CEO becomes bottleneck for decisions requiring coordination (sales vs delivery, growth vs profitability, risk vs speed). Organizational scalability limited—cannot add volume/complexity without overwhelming CEO with escalations. Heroics (CEO personal intervention) substitutes for scalable governance process.

hypothesis_framework.hypothesis: Debt covenants and regulatory constraints act as shadow veto authorities—management has formal decision authority but external constraints veto strategic options
supporting_evidence_sought: Evidence of strategic initiatives constrained by debt covenant requirements
Technology/capital investments limited by free cash flow after debt service
Operational consolidation prohibited by regulatory requirements (FedRAMP, UK Sovereign, China)
Management proposals denied or deferred due to external constraints vs internal decision opposition
Cost cuts prioritized over growth investments to maintain covenant compliance
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence of major capital investments funded despite debt constraints
Operational entity consolidation achieved despite regulatory constraints
Strategic initiatives pursued without debt holder or regulator approval
Growth investments prioritized over debt service

supporting: Debt structure: $1.3B First Lien with negative covenants, springing 5.0x leverage ratio (Stage 1)
AI strategy articulated Q3 2024 but capital allocation unclear—constrained by debt service
Q4 2024: customer-funded CapEx model—Rackspace cannot independently invest
Stage 1: FedRAMP authorizations invalidate on change of control—prevents government business sale
Stage 1: UK Sovereign Services architecturally isolated—cannot consolidate with global operations
Stage 1: China entity required by Cybersecurity Law—cannot consolidate with non-China operations
Layoffs 2021, 2023 for cost reduction despite customer service degradation
disconfirming: No evidence found of major strategic investments overcoming debt constraints
No evidence of regulatory constraints being negotiated or mitigated
Security incidents (ransomware 2022, zero-day 2024) forced reactive spending—confirms capital constrained for proactive investment

hypothesis_framework.notes: Hypothesis strongly supported. Debt holders (via covenants) and regulators (via compliance requirements) have de facto veto authority over strategic options. Management can propose strategies but execution constrained by external authorities who cannot be negotiated with. Debt covenants are contractually absolute. Regulatory requirements (FedRAMP, UK Sovereign, China) are structurally unchangeable. Result: Management formal authority exists but strategic option set constrained by shadow veto authorities.

hypothesis_framework.hypothesis: CEO role has accountability for business performance but lacks authority over strategic direction (Apollo), capital allocation (debt holders), or cost structure (regulatory fragmentation)—creating role constraint making CEO difficult to retain
supporting_evidence_sought: Three CEOs in three years indicating role difficulty or constraint
CEO replacements coinciding with strategic direction changes controlled by Apollo
CEO proposals for capital investment or strategic initiatives constrained by external authorities
Evidence that CEO can articulate strategy but cannot fund or structurally enable execution
Executive turnover beyond CEO (CFO, BU Presidents) suggesting broader authority/accountability mismatches
disconfirming_evidence_sought: CEO tenure stability (multi-year retention)
Evidence of CEO having autonomous authority over strategic direction without Apollo approval
CEO successful funding of strategic initiatives without external constraint
Evidence that CEO departures due to performance failure vs role constraint

supporting: Three CEOs in three years: Jones (to Sept 2022), Maletira (Sept 2022-Sept 2025), Kandiah (Sept 2025-present)
Jones departure Sept 2022 during failed strategic review—Apollo-controlled board decision
Maletira articulated strategy (services-led, AI) but execution capital-constrained
Apollo 57% control constrains CEO strategic options
Debt covenants constrain capital allocation
Regulatory fragmentation (Stage 1) prevents operational consolidation
CFO turnover: Molu departed Jan 2024; BU President Lillie departed Jan 2025
disconfirming: No evidence of CEO having autonomous strategic authority—Apollo approval required for material decisions
No evidence that CEO departures due to performance vs role constraint (ambiguous—both factors likely)

hypothesis_framework.notes: Hypothesis supported. CEO role structurally constrained: accountable for performance but lacks authority over strategic direction (Apollo controls), capital allocation (debt covenants constrain), cost structure (regulatory fragmentation prevents consolidation). Three CEOs in three years suggests role difficulty—limited strategic degrees of freedom makes turnaround challenging. Executive turnover beyond CEO (CFO, BU Presidents) indicates broader pattern of authority/accountability mismatches throughout organization.
